title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Book Reccomendation for Class
text:
Although I have already been assigned the book that I will be using for the ‚Äúliving with a book‚Äù assignment, I wanted to see what our LLM would produce when asking it about what book I should read


I have a semester long project in my class in which I will carry a book around with me the entire time. These are the book options: Buolamwini, Joy (2024). Unmasking AI: My Mission to Protect What Is Human in a World of Machines. Random House. Mollick, Ethan (2024). Co-Intelligence Living and Working with AI. Penguin. Summerfield, Christopher (2025). These Strange New Minds. How AI Learned to Talk and What It Means. Penguin. Bender, Emily & Hanna, Alex (2025). The AI Con. How to Fight Big Tech‚Äôs Hype and Create the Future We Want. HarperCollins. Bennett, Max (2023). A Brief History of Intelligence Evolution, AI, and the Five Breakthroughs That Made Our Brains. HarperCollins. Hoffman, Reid & Beato, Greg (2025). Superagency. What Could Possibly Go Right with Our AI Future. Authors Equity. Ananthaswamy, Anil (2024). Why Machines Learn. The Elegant Math Behind Modern AI. Penguin. Which book should I choose?



Good question! Picking a book you‚Äôll carry all semester depends on what you want out of the class: Do you want something more technical, more ethical / policy-oriented, more futuristic, more mathematical, more action / change oriented, etc.? I can walk you through how a few of these differ and which might suit different priorities‚Äîand then I can recommend one that seems strong for many students. You can use that plus your own preferences.

Here‚Äôs a breakdown of some of the options, strengths & trade-offs:



Book
What it focuses on / key themes
What you‚Äôll likely get out of it (benefits)
Potential downsides or what it may not provide as much of




Unmasking AI by Joy Buolamwini (2024)
A mixture of memoir + research; how bias, exclusion, discrimination show up in AI systems (especially vision / facial recognition), ‚Äúcoded gaze‚Äù, algorithmic justice, the social & ethical side of AI. (PenguinRandomhouse.com)
Very compelling if you care about ethics, fairness, social justice, human-rights implications, how people are affected. Good stories, good for framing AI in the real world. Makes ethical questions concrete. Great if you want to push for change or policy.
Might not go deep into the mathematics or the nuts & bolts of how AI works technically; might be less forward-looking in terms of speculative AI futures or cutting edge breakthroughs. If you want hard tech / math, this may feel lighter.


The AI Con: How to Fight Big Tech‚Äôs Hype and Create the Future We Want by Emily Bender & Alex Hanna (2025)
Critiques of hype in AI; demystifies what AI is/what it isn‚Äôt; shows how ‚ÄúBig Tech‚Äù uses hype; tools for deconstructing narratives; looks at ethical, social, economic, political impact, and power dynamics. (The Guardian)
Very strong if you want a critical lens; good for debates, policy, media literacy. If part of your project involves thinking about what people believe about AI, or how to push back / shape future AI use, this would give you a lot of material. Also timely.
Might be less inspiring if you want more optimistic / pro-technology vision; might be critical in tone (which you may like, but if you want something more balanced or future-imagining, may feel heavy). Possibly less technical detail.




Then there are some of the others that might offer different strengths. (I didn‚Äôt find as much detail in my quick search for all of them, so I‚Äôll approximate.)

Co-Intelligence: Living and Working with AI (Ethan Mollick) ‚Äì likely more about collaboration human + AI; maybe more about how we integrate AI in real life / organizations.
These Strange New Minds (Christopher Summerfield) ‚Äì sounds like it might explore how AI ‚Äúlearns to talk‚Äù and its implications; maybe more cognitive / neuroscientific / psychology aspects.
Why Machines Learn: The Elegant Math Behind Modern AI (Anil Ananthaswamy) ‚Äì more mathematical / technical depth; good if you want to understand models, algorithms, math behind AI.
Superagency (Reid Hoffman & Greg Beato) ‚Äì may lean toward what good futures might look like; more optimistic, imagining possibilities.
A Brief History of Intelligence, Evolution, AI, and the Five Breakthroughs ‚Ä¶ (Max Bennett) ‚Äì if you like history, evolution of intelligence, deep thinking over time; may offer a broad lens.


My recommendation:
If I were in your shoes, and wanted a book that balances ethical impact, relevance, good for discussions & projects, and helps me understand both what‚Äôs wrong and what to think about going forward, I‚Äôd pick Unmasking AI by Joy Buolamwini. It gives strong grounding in how the real world is affected ‚Äî bias, justice, societal harm ‚Äî but also pushes you to think about what should be done. Plus, it has good narrative elements, which makes it engaging all semester.
If instead you are more interested in critiquing current hype, power structures, narratives, etc., then The AI Con is also very strong.
If you tell me what your project is (theme / angle), or what you care most about (ethics, math, future, social justice, etc.), I can help you pick the best for you. Do you want me to match to your interests?



I would like a book with a pro AI argument. Which book should I choose?



If you want a book that makes a pro-AI or at least optimistic/pro-AI argument, here are the best picks from your list ‚Äî and which one I‚Äôd pick:




These books argue that AI can bring benefits, enhancements, or positive futures, rather than mostly warning about harms.

Superagency by Reid Hoffman & Greg Beato (2025)

Very much a positive / forward-looking argument. The authors argue that AI can increase human agency, act as a partner & amplifier in work, education, healthcare, etc. (Superagency)
They call for embracing AI, navigating its risks responsibly, but not letting fear freeze progress. (TechCrunch)

Co-Intelligence: Living and Working with AI by Ethan Mollick (2024)

This also has a generally positive stance: how humans and AI can collaborate; how using AI well can supercharge thinking & productivity. (MiddleWeb)
It gives guidance / rules for how to engage with AI in practice (human‚Äêin-the-loop, treating AI like a collaborator, etc.). (Forbes)







Superagency is more visionary, big picture, and optimistically ambitious. If you like imagining transformative futures, agency, what‚Äôs possible broadly, this is very strong.
Co-Intelligence is more practical, about day-to-day work, how people can actually use AI now, what to watch out for, how to adapt. If you want something you can apply sooner, that‚Äôs very useful.





If I were you and wanted a book with a pro-AI argument, I‚Äôd pick Superagency by Reid Hoffman & Greg Beato. It seems to lean more strongly toward an optimistic case, gives you inspiration + arguments for the future, which could be great for class discussions, essays, and imaginative projects.
If you want, I can also list some pros and cons of Superagency to make sure it aligns with your style / what you‚Äôre comfortable defending, so you‚Äôre confident with it. Do you want that?



I thought the LLM did a solid job of adjusting to the different preference that I provided regarding the specific positions and ideas of the book.
